title: Release v0.12.0 and prepare v0.13.0 development cycle
body:
## Summary

This PR completes the v0.12.0 release process and prepares the repository for the next v0.13.0 development cycle.

## What's Included

### ✅ v0.12.0 Release Completion
- **Complete pre-release preparation**: All code quality checks, testing, version verification, and documentation updates
- **Comprehensive CHANGELOG**: Added detailed v0.12.0 changelog with all major features, infrastructure improvements, security fixes, and deployment enhancements
- **Release script improvements**: Updated `release.py` with correct dependency order and removed outdated `release.bat`

### ✅ v0.12.0 Already Published & Live 🎉
- **All core Rust crates** published to crates.io v0.12.0
- **Python package** published to PyPI v0.12.0  
- **GitHub release** created: https://github.com/madesroches/micromegas/releases/tag/v0.12.0
- **Git tags** pushed for all releases

### 🔄 v0.13.0 Development Cycle Preparation  
- **Version bumps**: All components updated to v0.13.0
  - Rust workspace and all crate versions
  - Python package version
  - Analytics web app version
  - Updated internal dependency references
- **Lock file updates**: Regenerated Cargo.lock and package-lock.json

## Major v0.12.0 Features Delivered

- **Async span tracing revolution** with new proc macros
- **JSONB support** and **HTTP gateway** integration
- **Perfetto async spans** with SQL-powered trace generation  
- **Complete Python/SQL documentation** with visual diagrams
- **Security fixes** including CVE-2025-58160
- **Cloud deployment tools** and Rust 2024 edition upgrade

## Commits in this PR

- Complete pre-release preparation for v0.12.0
- Update CHANGELOG and release plan with final v0.12.0 details  
- Update release scripts with correct dependency order
- Bump version to 0.13.0 for next development cycle

## Ready for Merge

All release work is complete and the repository is ready for continued development on v0.13.0.

title: Refactor lakehouse views to use generate_process_jit_partitions
body:
## Summary
- Replace stream-level iteration with process-level partition generation in metrics and log views
- Use `generate_process_jit_partitions` instead of `generate_stream_jit_partitions` 
- Remove manual stream iteration loops and simplify error handling

## Changes
- **metrics_view.rs**: Use `generate_process_jit_partitions` with "metrics" tag
- **log_view.rs**: Use `generate_process_jit_partitions` with "log" tag
- Remove unused `list_process_streams_tagged` imports
- Eliminate manual stream iteration loops in both views
- Simplify error handling from stream-specific to process-level

## Performance Benefits
- Reduced database queries from per-stream to per-process
- Better parallelization with process-level batching
- Simplified code paths with fewer function calls
- Consistent partition generation pattern across all lakehouse views

## Test plan
- [✅] Build verification: `cargo build` - Success
- [✅] Code formatting: `cargo fmt` - Applied
- [✅] Lint check: `cargo clippy --workspace -- -D warnings` - Zero warnings  
- [✅] Test suite: All 53 tests passed (including 22 doctests)
- [✅] Package verification: `cargo check --package micromegas-analytics` - Success

## Implementation Details
Follows the pattern established in `async_events_view.rs` which already uses the process-level approach. The `thread_spans_view.rs` was analyzed but doesn't need refactoring as it processes single streams rather than multiple streams per process.

title: Consolidate Perfetto trace generation to use SQL-powered implementation
body:
## Summary
- Consolidate Perfetto trace generation by removing separate Python implementation in favor of SQL-powered version
- Fix race condition in JIT partition matching causing non-deterministic trace generation
- Clean up redundant code paths and parameters

## Changes
- **Consolidation**: Remove Python-based Perfetto writing code, now uses SQL `perfetto_trace_chunks()` function
- **Race condition fix**: Use inclusive inequalities (`<=`, `>=`) in partition time range matching
- **Code cleanup**: Remove unused `query_range` parameters from Rust Perfetto trace code
- **Type unification**: Merge duplicate `TimeRange` structs to use consistent `crate::time::TimeRange`
- **Improved logging**: Add debug output to track partition matching behavior
- **Shutdown handling**: Add proper synchronization to telemetry sink cleanup

## Problem Fixed
The partition matching logic used exclusive time range inequalities (`<`, `>`) which meant identical time ranges never matched, causing partitions to be unnecessarily recreated on every query. This led to non-deterministic results and performance issues.

## Test plan
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Code compiles successfully
- [x] Perfetto trace generation now uses unified SQL-powered implementation
- [x] Consistent results across different code paths

Closes #488

Remove mkdocs virtual environment from version control
body:
## Summary
- Remove mkdocs/venv directory from git tracking (17,382 files totaling 555k+ lines)
- Add mkdocs/venv/ to .gitignore to prevent future tracking

## Problem
The mkdocs/venv directory was accidentally committed to version control, adding massive repository bloat with platform-specific files that should never be tracked.

## Solution
Virtual environments contain generated files and platform-specific binaries that should be created locally using requirements files, not tracked in git.

## Test Plan
- [x] Verified mkdocs build still works with fresh virtual environments
- [x] Tested GitHub Actions workflow uses pip install from requirements.txt
- [x] Confirmed build-docs.py script creates docs-venv locally (already in .gitignore)

title: Update dependencies to latest compatible versions
body:
## Summary
Updates key dependencies to their latest compatible versions for improved security, performance, and feature support.

## Changes Made

### ✅ Successfully Updated Dependencies:
- **reqwest**: 0.12.4 → 0.12.23 (security and performance improvements)
- **sqlx**: 0.8.1 → 0.8.6 (bug fixes and PostgreSQL improvements)  
- **colored**: 2.x → 3.0.0 (improved terminal color support)
- **memoffset**: 0.6 → 0.9.1 (performance optimizations)
- **sysinfo**: 0.33 → 0.37.0 (better cross-platform system info)

### ✅ Patch Updates Applied:
- All DataFusion crates: v49.0.0 → v49.0.1
- hyper: 1.6.0 → 1.7.0
- proc-macro2, serde_json, and various other patch updates

### ❌ Updates Attempted but Reverted:
- **arrow-flight**: 55 → 56 (conflicts with DataFusion's Arrow v55 dependency)
- **tonic**: 0.12 → 0.14 (breaking changes - `tls` feature removed)

## Test plan
- [x] Build completes successfully
- [x] All workspace library tests pass
- [x] No compilation errors or warnings
- [x] Dependency conflicts resolved

## Notes
The updates were applied incrementally with build verification after each change. Major version updates that would cause breaking changes or dependency conflicts were properly reverted to maintain stability.

This brings the project's dependencies significantly more up-to-date while maintaining full compatibility.

title: Convert all unit tests to in-memory recording
body:
## Summary
- Convert all mixed-approach unit tests from external dependencies to in-memory recording
- Implement standardized test utilities with RAII cleanup patterns  
- Eliminate TelemetryGuardBuilder usage in unit tests for faster, more reliable testing
- Add comprehensive module documentation following Rust best practices

## Changes Made

### 🎯 **Core Achievement: 9/9 Mixed-Approach Tests Converted**
All problematic tests that mixed `TelemetryGuardBuilder` (external dependencies) with manual stream management have been successfully converted to pure in-memory recording.

#### **Phase 1: Infrastructure Setup**
- **New test utilities** (`rust/tracing/src/test_utils.rs`) with RAII cleanup
- **Enhanced InMemorySink** with complete implementation and helper methods  
- **Cross-crate availability** via `micromegas_tracing::test_utils`

#### **Phase 2: Mixed-Approach Test Conversions**
- **`log_tests.rs`**: 5/5 tests converted using hybrid approach (maintains original encoding/decoding logic + adds infrastructure verification)
- **`metrics_test.rs`**: 3/3 tests converted using same hybrid pattern
- **Zero `TelemetryGuardBuilder` usage** remaining in converted tests

#### **Phase 3: Final Conversions & Consolidation**  
- **`span_tests.rs`**: 1/1 test converted (final mixed-approach test)
- **Existing in-memory tests**: Validated and consolidated where beneficial
- **Async tests**: Maintained specialized working patterns with proper cleanup

### 🚀 **Performance & Reliability Improvements**
- **Speed**: All converted tests now run in ~0.01s (vs potential network timeouts)
- **Reliability**: Zero external dependencies, no HTTP calls, no database connections
- **Consistency**: Single standardized pattern with proper `#[serial]` annotations
- **Maintainability**: RAII cleanup prevents test interference

### 📚 **Documentation & Code Quality**
- **Module documentation**: Moved from lib.rs to individual module files following Rust best practices
- **Comprehensive plan**: Full implementation strategy and success metrics documented
- **Clean utilities**: Removed unused functions, streamlined imports

## Test Results
All test categories passing:
- ✅ **9 converted mixed-approach tests** (5 log + 3 metrics + 1 span)
- ✅ **6+ existing in-memory tests** (async span tests, specialized tests)  
- ✅ **~15 pure data structure tests** (unchanged, already optimal)
- 🚫 **2 integration tests** (correctly marked `#[ignore]` for external dependencies)

## Files Changed (11 files, +612/-37 lines)
- **Test files**: 4 files converted to in-memory recording
- **Infrastructure**: Test utilities, enhanced InMemorySink 
- **Documentation**: Module docs moved to proper locations
- **Plan**: Comprehensive implementation plan with success metrics

## Breaking Changes
None. All changes are internal to test infrastructure and maintain existing public APIs.

title: how to query doc
Async events
body:
## Summary
Complete implementation of async events view for micromegas telemetry system to enable debugging and analysis of async operations across threads.

• **Core async events view** - Process-scoped materialized view aggregating async span events from all thread streams
• **High-frequency optimization** - Minimal 10-field schema optimized for frequent async operations  
• **Timestamp fix** - Proper tick-to-nanosecond conversion resolving 1970 epoch issue
• **Comprehensive testing** - 12 Rust unit tests + 6 Python integration tests with process-based time ranges
• **Development tooling** - Python service management scripts and Jupyter notebook environment

## Key Features
- Cross-thread async operation visibility via `view_instance('async_events', process_id)`
- Parent-child span relationship tracking for nested async operations
- Duration analysis by matching begin/end event pairs
- Process info JOINs for contextual debugging
- Work-stealing scheduler compatibility across thread boundaries

## Test Plan
- [x] All Rust unit tests passing (async events view creation, block processing, high-frequency scenarios)
- [x] Python integration tests with realistic time ranges
- [x] End-to-end validation with telemetry generator
- [x] Service management scripts tested and verified
- [x] Code formatting and build validation

title: Async span tracing improvements and macro unification
body:

- Enhanced async span tracing infrastructure with call stack tracking
- Unified span instrumentation macros - `#[span_fn]` now handles both sync and async functions
- Removed deprecated `#[instrument_async]` macro in favor of unified approach
- Added comprehensive development guidelines documentation

## Key Changes
- **Async call stack tracking**: Improved async span instrumentation using `InstrumentedFuture`
- **Unified macro approach**: `#[span_fn]` now automatically detects sync vs async functions
- **Deprecated macro removal**: Eliminated `#[instrument_async]` and migrated all usages
- **Documentation**: Added CLAUDE.md and expanded AI_GUIDELINES.md with architecture overview and commands

## Test Results
All async span tests passing (3/3), verifying compatibility and functionality.

title: Fix Dependabot alert #21: Update tmp package to resolve CVE-2025-54798
body:
## Summary
- Fixes Dependabot security alert #21 (CVE-2025-54798)
- Updates vulnerable `tmp` package from 0.0.33 to secure version 0.2.4
- Resolves arbitrary temporary file write vulnerability via symbolic link exploitation

## Changes
- Added npm override for `tmp: "0.2.4"` in presentation template package.json
- Updated package-lock.json to enforce secure version across dependency tree
- Vulnerability was in transitive dependency: external-editor → tmp

## Security Impact
- **CVE**: CVE-2025-54798
- **Severity**: Low (CVSS 2.5)
- **Issue**: Arbitrary temporary file/directory write via symbolic link `dir` parameter
- **Fix**: Version 0.2.4 properly handles symbolic links in path resolution

## Test Plan
- [x] npm audit shows 0 vulnerabilities (was 6 before fix)
- [x] ESLint tests pass successfully
- [x] Package correctly updated to secure version 0.2.4
- [x] No breaking changes or functionality regression

Closes #21

title: Add comprehensive async tracing infrastructure with micromegas_main proc macro
body:
## Summary

• **micromegas_main proc macro**: Drop-in replacement for `#[tokio::main]` with automatic telemetry setup and tracing callbacks
• **Async span instrumentation**: Full support for async functions in `#[span_fn]` macro with `InstrumentedFuture` wrapper
• **Thread lifecycle management**: Proper thread stream registration/unregistration with tokio runtime integration  
• **Service migration**: All services now use `micromegas_main` for consistent telemetry configuration

## Key Features

- **Safe async tracing**: Uses `pin-project` for memory-safe future instrumentation
- **Thread safety**: Comprehensive concurrent access protection with proper cleanup on thread destruction  
- **Runtime integration**: `TracingRuntimeExt` trait for seamless tokio runtime configuration
- **Level overrides**: Configurable logging levels via proc macro parameters
- **Memory testing**: In-memory sink for reliable test verification without I/O dependencies

## Migration Impact

Services migrated from manual `TelemetryGuardBuilder` setup to `#[micromegas_main]`:
- `flight-sql-srv`
- `http-gateway` 
- `telemetry-admin-cli`
- `telemetry-ingestion-srv`

## Test Plan

- [x] Async span macro tests with event count verification
- [x] Sync span macro functionality preserved  
- [x] Thread safety tests under high concurrency
- [x] Thread parking flush behavior validation
- [x] Service integration with new proc macro
- [x] Memory leak prevention via proper stream unregistration

You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot show ignore conditions` will show all of the ignore conditions of the specified dependency - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/madesroches/micromegas/network/alerts).

title: presentation template & logo design

feat: Automate documentation publishing
body:
This commit introduces a GitHub Actions workflow to automatically build and publish the Rust documentation and the contents of the `doc` folder to GitHub Pages.

The workflow is configured to:
- Trigger on pushes to any branch for testing purposes.
- Build the Rustdoc for the `micromegas` crate.
- Copy the `doc` folder contents.
- Deploy the combined documentation to the `gh-pages` branch.

This will ensure that the documentation is always up-to-date and readily accessible.

feat: Add GitHub Pages permissions to publish-rust-docs workflow
body: This commit adds the necessary `pages: write` and `id-token: write` permissions to the `publish-rust-docs.yml` workflow. This resolves the "Permission denied" error encountered when the GitHub Actions bot attempts to deploy documentation to GitHub Pages.

docs: Correct workload definition in cost comparison docs
body:
The cost comparison documents were confusing the total number of events over the 90-day retention period with the monthly ingestion rate. This commit clarifies the workload definition by separating the total events from the monthly ingestion rate and updates the cost calculations accordingly.

Author: Gemini <gemini@google.com>

title: docs: Improve README, add CHANGELOG and CONTRIBUTING guides
body: Refactor README for better readability and structure. Extract detailed "Getting Started" instructions into a new file. Introduce a dedicated CHANGELOG.md for release history. Add a CONTRIBUTING.md to guide community contributions.

docs: Add and improve Rust documentation
body:
This commit addresses several documentation issues:
- Added comprehensive documentation to previously undocumented public structs and functions across various Rust crates.
- Corrected misplaced doc comments to ensure they are properly associated with their respective items.
- Attempted to fix unclosed HTML tags in . While some were fixed, others remain due to the file being auto-generated and the source  files being unavailable.
- Acknowledged the  crate filename collision as a known Cargo bug that cannot be fixed at the code level.

These changes were generated by Gemini.
